Dear II Fred CHARLES Baker:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
6/28/24. The inspection has determined substantial compliance with applicable licensing
statutes and rules.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Venus M. Decker,
Child Welfare Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided concerning seclusion documentation. It was
noted that the supervisor on duty may want to review the seclusion sheets at the
end of their shift to ensure all signatures and observations are noted. The
supervisor can then initiate the sheet.
2

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency Renewal inspection was completed on 04/03/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 4/14/2023. The agency was cited for 4 violations and none are
repeats this year. The agency has created a seclusion checklist and this was
reviewed. This checklist allows for the reason of seclusion to be entered along with
supervisior and director approval. The personnel files were organized and easy to
work through. All information was provided for performance evaluations.
Financial Overview
The agency has completed a financial planning and is able to continue operating as
needed and there were no financial concerns identified.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The agency is compliant with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Court Operated Facility, N/A.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were able to verbalize their program. They were positive concerning their
program and did not have any concerns.
Youth were able to discuss positive things occurring with them at this time. A DHHS
youth who has been in the detention placement for over 9 months, waiting
placement, was able to speak favorably about his placement and the staff that were
there. This speaks to the culture of the facility. There were no concerns noted by
youth.
3

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is well maintained and decorated in common areas. There were no
concerns identified.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
6/3/24

Venus M. Decker Date
